description.fi:
In the Laulettu Kalevala (The Sung Kalevala) audiobook, as the name suggests, the Karelian-Finnish epic Kalevala (1849) is performed in its entirety through song, using a variety of traditional folk melodies.

The first episode of the audiobook was released digitally on Kalevala Day, 28 February 2023.
The continuation will be released digitally in 2026:
	•	Episode 2 will be released on Kalevala Day, 28 February
	•	Episode 3, the final episode, on Runosong Day, 25 April

Episode 1 can be listened to on the etno.net website. The Laulettu Kalevala YouTube channel is currently under maintenance for technical reasons, but will return to use as soon as possible.

It is essential that the Kalevala, compiled and created by Elias Lönnrot based on Karelian, Finnish, and Ingrian runosongs, is heard and sung specifically as traditional sunosong, because that is what the epic fundamentally is. The Kalevala can be challenging to read, but through song it can be experienced in an entirely new way.

Rune singing once came close to extinction, but it has been successfully revitalized in recent decades. Some of the key figures in this revival can be heard in this audiobook. One of the project’s central aims is that, through the familiar epic, the listener may gain access to the vast world of Baltic-Finnic runosong and folk poetry.

Working Group

Voice theather Iki-Turso: Eila Hartikainen, Taito Hoffrén, Maari Kallberg, Ilona Korhonen, Heikki Laitinen & Anna-Kaisa Liedes

The Laulettu Kalevala audiobook is part of the recording series of the Folk Music Department at the Sibelius Academy, University of the Arts Helsinki.

The final production and release of the audiobook in 2026 are funded by the Kalevala Society.

The project as a whole was funded during 2021–2023 by:
Jenny and Antti Wihuri Foundation, Kalevala Society, Finnish Cultural Foundation, Niilo Helander Foundation, and the Arts Promotion Centre Finland.
description.en: Sung Kalevala is a long-term audiobook project that brings the poems of Kalevala to life through traditional folk music and singing.

description.fi:
Piot [Feast] depicts joyful celebrations based on texts from the Baltic-Finnic peoples. The work itself is a small celebration, a feast - while at the same time it is a grand celebration of the female voice. Dedicated to folk music, the versatile musician, Doctor of Music, Docent of Folk Music, and Artist Professor Ilona Korhonen has composed and arranged a female choir work that remains faithful to traditional song styles and heritage texts of the Baltic-Finnic region. The piece resonates with the bone-shaking power characteristic of the Baltic-Finnic vocal tradition.

All singers in the ensemble are professional musicians - folk singers holding Master’s and Doctoral degrees in music;  Hanni Autere, Juulia Björn, Charlotta Hagfors, Emilia Kallonen, Anna E. Karvonen, Amanda Kauranne, Ilona Korhonen, Emmi Kuittinen, Pia Rask, Ulla Silvennoinen, Anni Tolvanen, Mira Törmälä

Piot received its world premiere in June 2023 as a commissioned piece for Tampere Vocal Music Festival (Tampereen Sävel). In 2026, pihla folk will release the piece as an album.

Starting international Finno-Ugric cooperation in Estonia together with Sattuma duo. Karelian and Finnish folk music at Finno-Ugric Days on October 20-21, 2023 at Õpetajate Maja, Tallinn and at Estonian National Museum, Tartu.

Funding: Ministry of Education and Culture, Music Promotion Foundation.
